result.markdown:
# Events

So as stated, shifted from providing a network, to providing raw event data.
Opinions?

Example:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
nodes <- data.frame(
  id   = c("1", "2", "3"),
  time = c(0, 1, 2)
)
edges <- data.frame(
  i    = c("1", "1"),
  j    = c("2", "3"),
  time = c(1, 2)
)

ev <- make_events(nodes = nodes, edges = edges)
ev
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
$times
  event_id t
1        1 0
2        2 1
3        3 2

$nodes
  event_id id
1        1  1
2        2  2
3        3  3

$edges
  event_id i j
1        2 1 2
2        3 1 3

attr(,"class")
[1] "hg_events" "list"     
```


:::
:::


In the case you only have `edges`, the `make_events()` function will implicitly
generate the nodes as they appear in `edges`. Note this is assuming that nodes
join the network at the first time in which they appear in `edges`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
edges <- data.frame(
  i    = c("1", "1"),
  j    = c("2", "3"),
  time = c(1, 2)
)

hawkesNet::make_events(edges = edges)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
$times
  event_id t
1        1 1
2        2 2

$nodes
     event_id id
NA          1  1
NA.1        1  2
NA.2        2  3

$edges
  event_id i j
1        1 1 2
2        2 1 3

attr(,"class")
[1] "hg_events" "list"     
```


:::
:::


There are also two useful helpers for working with events, `edges_by_event()` and
`nodes_by_event()`:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
edges_by_event(ev)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[[1]]
[1] i j
<0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)

[[2]]
  i j
1 1 2

[[3]]
  i j
1 1 3
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
nodes_by_event(ev)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[[1]]
  id
1  1

[[2]]
  id
1  2

[[3]]
  id
1  3
```


:::
:::
